Method Detail

getStackTrace

public static java.lang.String getStackTrace(java.lang.Throwable exception)
Convenience method: Extract the stacktrace from an Exception and returns it as a String.

Parameters:
exception - the exception to expand
Returns:
the stacktrace from the exception, as a String

join

public static java.lang.String join(java.util.Collection c,
                                    java.lang.String delimiter)

Concatenate all elements in a collection with a given delimiter. For example if a list contains "foo", "bar", and "baz" and the delimiter is ":" the returned string will be

"foo:bar:baz"

If any of the collection's elements are null the empty string will simply be used.

Parameters:
c - The collection which elements will be concatenated as strings
delimiter - symbol(s) to put in between elements
Returns:
A string representation of the collection. If the collection is empty the empty string will be returned.
Throws:
java.lang.NullPointerException - if the collection or delimiter is null.

join

public static java.lang.String join(java.lang.Object[] a,
                                    java.lang.String delimiter)
See join(Collection, String).

flush

public static java.lang.String flush(java.io.Reader r)
                              throws java.io.IOException
Read all character data from r and create a String based on that data. The reader is guaranteed to be closed when this method returns.

This method is optimized to only allocate the needed space for the final string and not any intermediate buffers.

Parameters:
r - the reader to flush
Returns:
a string representation of the character stream
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if failing to read from r

flush

public static java.lang.String flush(java.io.InputStream in)
                              throws java.io.IOException
As flush(java.io.Reader), but operate on a InputStream

Parameters:
in - the input stream to flush
Returns:
a string representation of the input stream
Throws:
java.io.IOException - if failing to read from in

flushLocal

public static java.lang.String flushLocal(java.io.Reader r)
Read all character data from r and create a String based on that data. The reader is guaranteed to be closed when this method returns.

The difference from this method to flush(java.io.Reader) is that it can not throw an IOException. It is expected that the caller guarantees that the character stream is based on a local memory buffer.

This method is optimized to only allocate the needed space for the final string and not any intermediate buffers.

Parameters:
r - the reader to flush
Returns:
a string representation of the character stream
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - if failing to read from r

flushLocal

public static java.lang.String flushLocal(java.io.InputStream in)
As flushLocal(java.io.Reader), but operate on a InputStream

Parameters:
in - the input stream to flush
Returns:
a string representation of the input stream
Throws:
java.lang.RuntimeException - if failing to read from in

asCharSequence

public static java.lang.CharSequence asCharSequence(char[] chars)
Wrap a char array as a CharSequence without doing any memory- allocations or copying.

Note that since the original array underneath the returned character sequence is exactly chars any changes made to chars will be reflected in the returned character sequence as well.

Parameters:
chars - the character array to wrap
Returns:
chars wrapped as a CharSequence

indexOf

public static int indexOf(char c,
                          java.lang.CharSequence chars)
Finds the first index of the occurence of c in chars or returns -1.

Parameters:
c - the character to look for
chars - the character sequence to search in
Returns:
the index for which chars.charAt(i) == c or -1 if c doesn't exist in chars

indexOf

public static int indexOf(char c,
                          int offset,
                          java.lang.CharSequence chars)
Finds the first index of the occurence of c in chars or returns -1.

Parameters:
c - the character to look for
chars - the character sequence to search in
Returns:
the index for which chars.charAt(i) == c or -1 if c doesn't exist in chars
